Biodiversity at Helen’s Hill Estate. Part 1

Written by
madeline
Posted in
vineyard
Tagged
Australian animal, bugs, Helen's Hill, Helen's Hill Estate, Helen's Hill Wines, Intergrated Pest Management, vineyard, Yarra Valley

Integrated Pest Management (IPM)

 

Helen’s Hill is dedicated to taking what Mother Nature gave us and putting it in the bottle with minimal handling and processing, and to do that we have to make sure Mother Nature is at her best. Encouraging biodiversity in our vineyard is key to the health of our vines and ultimately the quality of the fruit we are able to produce. A healthy and diverse ecosystem maintains balance and reduces the likelihood of one species becoming dominant. Integrated Pest Management (IPM) is about understanding your ecosystem and harnessing its power and it is a big part of our vineyard management strategy here at Helen’s Hill
“When we kill off the natural enemies of a pest, we inherit their work” (Carl Huffaker, University of California, Berkley). The use of harsh insecticides may wipe out a problem pest but takes out everything else with it. There is nothing I enjoy more than seeing our ecosystem at work and by encouraging natural predators of problem vineyard pests, we dramatically reduce the need for insecticides or bird netting in our vineyard.
So how do we encourage biodiversity at Helen’s Hill? The planting of native grasses, development of bushland, cover crops and grasses in the inter rows and dedicated insectariums provide natural habitat for many beneficials like parasitic wasps, spiders, lady bugs, territorial birds and some mites. By increasing plant diversity, rather than just rows and rows of vines with little else, we are providing alternative food and shelter sources and are able to sustain greater biodiversity.

 Letting the grass grow long in between the rows during the spring and summer may look untidy….but it serves a much greater purpose!

 

Here are a few of our friends to look out for

1. The Orb Weaving Spider

Winter pruning highlights the number of beneficial insects we have making their home in the vineyard and it is always with wonder that I admire the precision and beauty of the work of the Golden Orb spider that lives in our vineyard tireless removing unwanted insect pests.

An Orb Weaver includes any spider that makes an orb web – round webs built on a radiating structure of spokes like a bicycle wheel. The female is larger than the male (actually quite a common occurrence in the world of nature).  The Orb is brown in colour with a variety of patterns on the abdomen.  They build webs after sunset and sit in the middle at night waiting for insects.  During the day they retreat to the shelter of tree trunks or leaves. If the web was undamaged during the night they will leave it intact but generally they will eat the web and re-spin it every night.  Females live approximately 12 months and make egg sacks near their retreat in late summer early autumn.  Eggs hatch in the following summer and the cycle starts again.

 

 

 

2. Victoria and Doreen.

Who are these women you ask? Actually they are famous in the industry and a movie titled Wine, Women and Beneficial Vineyard Mites was made in the late 1990’s singing their praises so it is always with pleasure that I see them in my travels. Their full names are Amblyseius “Victoria” and Typhlodromus “Doreen” and they are mites. Mites have 4 pairs of legs where insects have 3. Under favourable conditions with enough food they will recycle continuously. They overwinter in bark and plant debris when the climate is cool enough and consume pest mites, their larvae and eggs in large numbers. The females (larger than the males) provide the most benefit to the vineyard as they have the larger appetite as it appears that the males have other interests!

 

 

3. Wedge Tailed Eagle

Our vineyard has a back yard of 250acres of native bushland and home to a family of majestic Wedge Tailed Eagles, Australia’s largest raptor (bird of prey). To be witness to the flight of these magnificent birds is one of the pleasures of working outdoors, and I delight in seeing them soaring over the vineyard- particularly in the summer – as their presence certainly gives our unwelcome species of birds (the Indian Mynah and the Starling) a reason to stop eating our grapes and hide somewhere else!

 

 

 

IPM is a not just about having respect for our environment….it’s about understanding that Mother Nature is better than us at taking care of things. Helping her do her work provides us with the healthiest vineyard possible so we can make the best tasting wine.

Look out for part 2 – soil biodiversity in a couple of weeks!

Cheers,

Robyn McIntosh
